title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
summary: Set in the American South during the 1930s, this novel follows young Scout Finch as she learns about morality, empathy, and racial injustice through her father's defense of a black man wrongly accused of rape.

author: George Orwell
summary: In a totalitarian society ruled by the Party and its leader, Big Brother, protagonist Winston Smith rebels against the oppressive regime and grapples with surveillance, censorship, and the nature of truth.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
summary: A witty and insightful portrayal of societal norms and gender roles in early 19th-century England, this novel follows the spirited Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates love, marriage, and social class.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
summary: Set in the Roaring Twenties, this novel explores the American Dream and the disillusionment of the post-World War I era through the eyes of narrator Nick Carraway and his enigmatic neighbor Jay Gatsby.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
summary: Narrated by Holden Caulfield, a disillusioned teenager, this novel explores themes of alienation, identity, and the search for authenticity as Holden navigates the complexities of adolescence in post-World War II America.
